edu.lehigh.cse.lol

Class Tilt

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.lehigh.cse.lol.Tilt

  • public class Tilt
extends java.lang.Object
    Tilt provides a mechanism for moving actors on the screen. To use tilt, you must enable it for a level, and also indicate that some actors move via tilting. Tilt has two flavors: tilt can cause gravitational effects, where a sustained tilt causes acceleration (this is the default), or it can cause actors to move with a fixed velocity. Be careful when using tilt. Different phones' accelerometers vary in terms of sensitivity. It is possible to set multipliers and/or caps on the effect of Tilt, but these may not suffice to make your game playable and enjoyable.

    • Method Detail

      • enable

        public static void enable(float xGravityMax,
                          float yGravityMax)
        Turn on accelerometer support so that tilt can control actors in this level
        Parameters:
        xGravityMax - Max X force that the accelerometer can produce
        yGravityMax - Max Y force that the accelerometer can produce

      • setAsVelocity

        public static void setAsVelocity(boolean toggle)
        This method lets us change the behavior of tilt, so that instead of applying a force, we directly set the velocity of objects using the accelerometer data.
        Parameters:
        toggle - This should usually be false. Setting it to true means that tilt does not cause forces upon objects, but instead the tilt of the phone directly sets velocities

      • setGravityMultiplier

        public static void setGravityMultiplier(float multiplier)
        Use this to make the accelerometer more or less responsive, by multiplying accelerometer values by a constant.
        Parameters:
        multiplier - The constant that should be multiplied by the accelerometer data. This can be a fraction, like 0.5f, to make the accelerometer less sensitive
